text:
What's your favorite editor to use? I use VS Code but <https://medium.com/@greg_dizzia/how-to-create-your-own-micro-monopoly-a-7-step-guide-to-owning-a-market-for-massive-corporations-b0d02be71dbf|I would prefer to not use it.>
The IntelliJ plugin seems out of date.

elements.text: What's your favorite editor to use? I use VS Code but

text: I know that this guide is satire, but the final thoughts just read like pure microsoft hate for the sake of pointing to them as the big evil guy that got slapped on the wrist because of monopoly stuff in the past

text: <@UDB26738Q> hah maybe it's finally time that I get comfortable with vim/emacs. I had a look at sublime text but julia is only supported on ST4...

text: I’ve been convinced by <@U8D9768Q6> emoji campaign and am trying out :emacs:  for the first time. Enjoying it a lot.

text: I'm kinda frustrated with emacs, but never been able to give anything else a solid try. I sometimes think modal editing would be nice. I know it's possible with emacs, but again, never gave it a solid try. Also, some ide-like features are missing or hard to set up... I guess (never really used an IDE)

elements.text: I'm kinda frustrated with emacs, but never been able to give anything else a solid try. I sometimes think modal editing would be nice. I know it's possible with emacs, but again, never gave it a solid try. Also, some ide-like features are missing or hard to set up... I guess (never really used an IDE)

text: I just use VSCode. It's nice if you do cross platform dev because there's no context shift. Supports all languages I use, has nice extensions, and works with minimal fuss. If that's off the table I mean, you're probably best off using VIM or Emacs.

elements.text: I just use VSCode. It's nice if you do cross platform dev because there's no context shift. Supports all languages I use, has nice extensions, and works with minimal fuss. If that's off the table I mean, you're probably best off using VIM or Emacs.

text: I really love emacs. There are some things it's not good at, but I can't stand to use any other IDE anymore.

elements.text: I really love emacs. There are some things it's not good at, but I can't stand to use any other IDE anymore.

text: <@U93BUBZP0> Have you heard of evil? It basically gives emacs, the power of vim (atleast that's what I've heard, never have been a fan of emacs personally :P).

elements.text: Have you heard of evil? It basically gives emacs, the power of vim (atleast that's what I've heard, never have been a fan of emacs personally :P).

text: I use VSCode or even like Micro. Tbh I find that with dynamic languages like Julia I don't miss plugins.

elements.text: I use VSCode or even like Micro. Tbh I find that with dynamic languages like Julia I don't miss plugins.
for haskell VS code is <3<3<3

text: <@UPUBAM63X> yep, rust-analyzer for Rust is also invaluable. I'm super thankful for the ppl making `julia-vscode` don't get me wrong, but using Rust/Haskell makes me wish so badly that Julia had static analysis.

yep, rust-analyzer for Rust is also invaluable. I'm super thankful for the ppl making
julia-vscode
don't get me wrong, but using Rust/Haskell makes me wish so badly that Julia had static analysis.

text:
it actually makes learning a language a lot easier.
For haskell the tool tips actually give refactoring advice it's insane. Like I've learned to write better code by basically getting minicode reviews from a little plugin lol
